docs.lead_paragraph: A drug prescribed for severe acne should not be used by women before or during pregnancy because it can cause severe birth defects, federal health officials said today. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said some pregnant women were taking the drug, isotretinoin, which is marketed by Roche Pharmaceuticals under the name Accutane, despite warnings to doctors and consumers about its dangers.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Doctors Warn Women About an Acne Drug

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush said today that the Supreme Court had interpreted the Constitution too broadly in its 1973 ruling that established the right to abortion. ''Roe v. Wade was a reach,'' Mr. Bush said crisply and unequivocally at a news conference here. ''It overstepped the Constitutional bounds, as far as I'm concerned.''

headline.main: Bush, Pressed to Clarify Views, Repeats Opposition to Abortion

docs.lead_paragraph: Adam Graves took the ice for the Rangers last night against the Hurricanes and his longtime buddy, Carolina Coach Paul Maurice, wearing the captain's ''C'' that has been his since Brian Leetch was injured in late November. But he carried heavier burdens. He played a few hours after bringing his wife, Violet, home after a week in the hospital. His older daughters, Montana and Madison, missed their mother. Because of a complication in her pregnancy, Violet Graves gave birth prematurely to twin boys Friday night. Their names are Jaxon and Logan and they arrived almost three months before their due date. Both weighed in at about two pounds. They remain in the hospital, in stable condition.

headline.main: Leader on Ice, and in the Real World

docs.abstract: Article discusses leadership qualities of New York Rangers hockey player Adam Graves; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women who show signs that their fetuses may have anemia, which in serious cases can require treatment even before the baby is born, have traditionally been advised to go undergo diagnostic procedures that involve physically piercing their wombs. The tests are effective at confirming the disease but can cause their own risk to the mother or fetus.

headline.main: A Safer, Simpler Way to Test a Fetus

docs.abstract: New study finds that Doppler ultrasound may be simpler, safer and less expensive way to diagnose fetal anemia (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Last fall, the New York State Education Department released the results of a fourth-grade math test and eighth-grade math and language tests. It will come as no surprise to hear that the numbers for students in New York City were dreadful. About two-thirds of city eighth graders failed the English language arts test, and about three-quarters failed in math; half the fourth graders failed the math test. The results provided fuel for those who felt that New York City schools are underfinanced, that the city uses too many uncertified teachers, that academic standards are low, that junior high schools are neglected and that the tests themselves are unfair. There's some merit in all these notions. What was not said, however, was the obvious: that the city districts that performed poorly, like those that performed well, scored almost exactly as the socioeconomic status of the children in them would have predicted. You could have predicted the fourth-grade test scores of all but one of the city's 32 districts merely by knowing the percentage of students in a given district who qualified for a free lunch. Only a few dozen of the city's 675 elementary schools scored well despite high poverty rates. In other words, good schools aren't doing that much good, and bad schools aren't doing that much harm. This is the case in virtually every big city in the country. Though over the past 35 years we have poured billions of dollars into inner-city schools, and though we have fiddled with practically everything you could think to fiddle with, we have done almost nothing to raise the trajectory of ghetto children. This is a fact, but it is one of those painful facts that it seems better to ignore. Why say anything that could discourage the children, parents and teachers who so desperately need encouragement? Why give aid and comfort to the opponents of high standards? After all, we know that some schools succeed where others fail. We know that some reforms work better than others. In a recently published book, ''Choosing Equality,'' Joseph P. Viteritti, a professor of public policy at New York University, describes the failure of one innovation after another before embarking on a defense of the one reform he believes in, school choice. Or perhaps, if the answer isn't choice, it's something else. Surely there must be some way of making a difference in the lives of poor children.
docs.abstract: James Traub article holds efforts to improve inner city schools have done little to raise trajectory of ghetto children; says educational reform cannot close achievement gap separating poor children from their wealthier, largely suburban counterparts; holds much of our political discourse is predicated on flawed view that school, by itself, can cure poverty; says moving families out of ghetto environment is most effective solution; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Maternity clothes took a turn toward clingier, bulge-hugging lines last year. Now, they're downright eye-popping in sexy materials like leather and see-through silk and in styles as revealing as 30 extra pounds of human upholstery will allow. Procreation, a new maternity line at Barneys New York, offers tight silk-and-Lycra sweaters ($140), Techno capri pants ($180) and a hot-pink cigarette skirt with a slit ($120). L'Atessa, also at Barneys, is even racier, with bikinis ($145) and silk sarongs ($140), near right; and black leather pants ($358) and fitted tank tops ($140), far right.
docs.abstract: Maternity clothes, which took turn toward clingier, bulge-hugging lines last year, are now available in sexy materials and more revealing styles; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Adding an abortion case to its docket for the first time in eight years, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a Nebraska law banning a procedure that the state calls partial birth abortion is constitutional. The justices plan to hear the case in April and decide it by early summer. The election-year ruling could have a substantial impact on the fractious politics of abortion, although it may not resolve questions about all the similar, but differently worded, prohibitions that 30 states have adopted in recent years.

headline.main: JUSTICES TO RULE ON LAW THAT BANS ABORTION METHOD

docs.abstract: Supreme Court agrees to decide constitutionality of Nebraska law banning 'partial-birth' abortion; case is first on abortion added to docket in eight years, and election-year ruling this summer could have impact on fractious politics of abortion; broadly-written Nebraska law, lacking exception to protect mother's health, was struck down by lower court that also ruled against similar laws in Iowa and Arkansas (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Maritza Maldonando thought, back in August 1995, that it would be just an innocent, uneventful two-week vacation to New York City. What she got instead, she said, was ''instability'' and exile from her native Dominican Republic. At the time, Ms. Maldonando was a second lieutenant and a psychologist in the Dominican Army, and she was seven months pregnant. Her immediate supervisor gave her permission to travel to the States. When Ms. Maldonando arrived, she started bleeding severely because of medical problems related to her pregnancy, she recalled. Too ill to travel, she was forced to stay past the time allotted for a tourist visa.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Vacation Turns Into a Penniless Exile

docs.abstract: Maritza Maldonando, Dominican in US illegally, gets help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; photo (S)
